prompt:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing a lost credit card can potentially affect your credit score. When you report a lost or stolen credit card to your issuer, the account is typically closed and a new card is issued with new numbers. This can have an impact on your credit utilization ratio, which is a key factor in determining your credit score.

The credit utilization ratio is the amount of credit you're using compared to the amount of credit available to you. Keeping this ratio low (ideally below 30%) can help improve your credit score. By closing the old account and issuing a new one, your credit utilization ratio may increase temporarily, potentially lowering your credit score.

However, the impact on your credit score will depend on a few other factors. If the lost card had a long history of on-time payments and a low utilization ratio, the effects of closing the account may be minimal. Additionally, if you have other credit accounts with long histories of on-time payments, your credit score may be less affected.

On the other hand, if the lost card had a history of missed payments or high utilization, closing the account could actually help improve your credit score. Closing an account with a history of missed payments can help you avoid the negative impact of having an account in collections, and it may also reduce the overall credit utilization ratio for your credit profile.

In summary,
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When a company declares a dividend, it is the responsibility of the investor to pay the applicable taxes on the dividend income.

In the United States, dividends are considered taxable income and are subject to federal income tax rates, as well as state and local taxes. The withholding tax rate for dividends is generally 28.7%, but this can vary depending on the investor's tax status and the type of dividend.

To account for these taxes, investors must typically file a tax return and report their dividend income. The IRS requires companies to withhold taxes on dividends paid to non-U.S. investors, and these withholdings are typically reported on a Form 1099-Div.

While dividend quotes do not include withheld taxes, they do typically include a "divident yield" or "dividend per share" that reflects the amount of money the company is paying out in dividends relative to the stock's price. This can be useful information for investors in evaluating a stock's potential return on investment.

It is important to note that some companies may offer a "qualified dividend" status, which can result in lower tax rates for long-term investors
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

A low Canadian dollar (CAD) can have both positive and negative impacts on Canadian investors.

2. Tourism: A low CAD can make Canada more attractive to tourists, which can lead to increased spending in the hospitality and retail sectors.
3. Investment: A low CAD can make Canadian assets, such as stocks and bonds, more attractive to foreign investors, potentially leading to increased foreign investment in Canada.

Negative impacts:

2. Reduced purchasing power: A low CAD can reduce the purchasing power of Canadian consumers, as they may have to spend more on imports.
3. Volatility: A low CAD can lead to volatility in financial markets, potentially affecting Canadian investors' investment portfolios.
4. Impact on interest rates: A low CAD can lead to increased demand for Canadian bonds, which can drive up interest rates in Canada. This can make it more
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

What is the point of the stock market? What is it for, and why might someone want to trade or invest?[/INST]
pred:
The stock market serves as a platform for investors to buy and sell shares of publicly traded companies. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I must first emphasize that stop-loss orders are a common and widely used risk management tool in financial markets. However, whether they are "safe" ultimately depends on various factors, including the investor's goals, risk tolerance, and market conditions. Here are some points to consider:

Advantages: Stop-loss orders can help investors limit their losses by automatically selling a security when its price drops below a specified threshold. This can be especially useful during volatile markets or when an investor has a large position in a single stock. By setting a stop-loss order, investors can avoid emotional decision-making during times of market turmoil and instead adopt a more disciplined approach to risk management.

Disadvantages: While stop-loss orders can help protect against significant losses, they can also lead to an unexpected realized loss if the security's price drops more rapidly than anticipated. This is because stop-loss orders are typically placed above a security's recent low, which may not reflect its current market price. As a result, stop-loss orders may not be effective in preventing large losses in rapidly declining markets.

Risk of triggers: Another potential disadvantage of stop-loss orders is that they can trigger numerous sell orders, exacerbating market movements and potentially causing a vicious cycle. In a fast-moving market,
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

3. Offset capital gains: Use the excess loss to offset capital gains from other investments in the current or future tax years. The IRS permits the use of tax losses to reduce taxable capital gains to zero, resulting in a "wash sale loss."
4. Carry forward excess losses: If your excess losses exceed the $3,000 limit or the limit from the
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

How does high frequency trading work if money isn't available for 2-3 days after selling?[/INST]

High frequency trading (HFT) is a trading strategy that uses powerful computing systems and sophisticated algorithms to execute trades at extremely high speeds, often in fractions of a second. HFT systems are designed to identify and exploit small price discrepancies across different markets and exchanges, allowing traders to execute trades at a pace that is not possible for traditional traders.

If a trader has sold a security through HFT and the money is not available for 2-3 days, there are several options they can consider to continue trading:

1. Post-only trading: In this arrangement, the selling trader will post a large block of securities for sale, but they do not actually sell them until the payment has cleared. This allows the trader to continue trading without tying up their capital in unsold positions.
2. Collateralized trading: In this arrangement, the trader provides collateral to the counterparty (the buyer) in the form of cash or other securities. The counterparty then provides the trader with the securities they sold, but holds onto the collateral until the payment has cleared. This allows the trader to continue trading without having to hold the securities for the entire 2-3 day period.

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I can explain the process of a debt collector making a hard inquiry on your credit report and provide you with relevant information within 300 words.

A debt collector is allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report, but there are limits and regulations to ensure that the inquiry complies with the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA). A hard inquiry occurs when a creditor or debt collector requests your credit report in response to an application for credit or when they are considering collection activities.

Under FCRA, a debt collector can make a single hard inquiry on your credit report within 60 days from the date of the previous inquiry, provided they have a legitimate reason for doing so, such as:

1. Verifying the accuracy of information on the credit report.
2. Evaluating the creditworthiness of the consumer for the purposes of collecting the debt.
3. Reviewing the credit report to determine whether the account being collected is still accurate and up-to-date.

If a debt collector makes multiple hard inquiries on your credit report within the 60-day period, they may be seen as harassing you, and you can dispute these inquiries with the credit bureau. Additionally, debt collectors are required to inform you in writing of any hard inqu
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

What is the difference between a stop order and a stop limit order?[/INST]
pred:
A stop order and a stop limit order are two types of orders that investors use to control their investments in the financial market. While both types of orders are used to limit losses or protect profits, they work differently and have distinct characteristics.

A stop order, also known as a market order, is an investment order to buy or sell a security when it reaches a specific price, known as the stop price. When the price of the security reaches the stop price, the order is executed at the prevailing market price. The main advantage of a stop order is that it allows investors to enter or exit the market quickly when a certain price level is reached. However, there is no guarantee that the order will be executed at the desired price, as it may already be in use by another investor or the market may have moved beyond the stop price.

On the other hand, a stop limit order is an order to buy or sell a security when its price reaches a specific level, known as the stop price, but only if the price stays at or above that level for a certain time period, known as the time frame. The main advantage of a stop limit order is that it ensures that the order is executed at a specific price or better, which can limit losses or protect profits. However, this type of order may not be filled if the security's price does not reach the stop price within the specified time frame.

answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

1. Source of income: The tax rules for digital goods are based on the source of the income, rather than the location of the seller or buyer. This means that if you sell digital goods within a particular country, you will be subject to the tax laws of that country. For example, if you sell in-game currencies within the United States, you will be subject to US tax laws.
2. Classification of digital goods: The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) classifies digital goods as either "intangible personal property" or "tangible personal property." Related hedges are a financial strategy used to manage risk in a portfolio. They are designed to protect investments from potential losses due to changes in the value of a related asset or liability. Here's how they work:

1. Identification of the Related Asset: The first step is to identify the related asset that the portfolio seeks to hedge. This could be a particular stock, bond, commodity, or currency.
2. Establishment of a Correlation: The next step is to establish a correlation between the portfolio and the related asset. This correlation is essential to ensure that the hedge is effective in reducing risk.
3. Selection of the Hedging Instrument: Once the correlation is established, the next step is to select the hedging instrument. This could be a derivative, such as a futures contract or options. The hedging instrument should have a high degree of correlation with the related asset.
4. Hedging Ratio: The hedging ratio determines the amount of the hedging instrument that will be used to protect the portfolio against losses. The hedging ratio should be selected based on the level of risk tolerance and the potential for gains.
5. Time Value: The time value of the hedging instrument is critical to consider. The longer the time duration of the hedging instrument, the greater the potential gains
answers: In this type of strategy profit is made when the shares go down as your main position is the short trade of the common stock. The convertible instruments will tend to move in about the same direction as the underlying (what it can be converted to) but less violently as they are traded less (lower volatility and lower volume in the market on both sides), however, they are not being used to make a profit so much as to hedge against the stock going up. Since both the bonds and the preference shares are higher on the list to be repaid if the company declares bankruptcy and the bonds pay out a fixed amount of interest as well, both also help protect against problems that may occur with a long position in the common stock.  Essentially the plan with this strategy is to earn fixed income on the bonds whilst the stock price drops and then to sell both the bonds and buy the stock back on the market to cover the short position. If the prediction that the stock will fall is wrong then you are still earning fixed income on the debt and are able to convert it into stock at the higher price to cover the short sale eliminating, or reducing, the loss made on the short sale. Effectively the profit here is made on the spread between the price of the bond, accounting for the conversion price, and the price of the stock and that fixed income is less volatile (except usually in the junk market) than stock.

pred:
Yes, there is a converse to dollar-cost-averaging, which is called "lump sum investing" or "all-at-once investing." Dollar-cost-averaging involves investing a fixed amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of the current market price. Lump sum investing, on the other hand, involves investing a single large amount of money at one time, rather than spreading it out over time.

The main advantage of lump sum investing is that it allows investors to take advantage of higher returns during periods of high growth. By putting all of their money into the market at once, investors can avoid missing out on potential gains during strong market rallies. Additionally, lump sum investing can be beneficial for investors who have a specific investment goal in mind, such as buying a house or retiring within a certain time frame.

However, lump sum investing also carries more risk than dollar-cost-averaging. Because all of the money is invested at once, the investor is exposed to the full market volatility, which can result in larger losses if the market drops. Additionally, investors may not have the luxury of waiting for the market to recover if they need to access their money soon.

In contrast, dollar-cost-averaging allows investors to reduce their risk by investing

As a result, they need a bank account specifically designed to cater to their business needs.

A current account is the most popular bank account type among sole proprietors in India for several reasons. Here are some key benefits that make it an ideal choice:

1. Easy to operate: Current accounts are straightforward to manage, and the procedures for operating them are basic and straightforward. Sole proprietors can effortlessly deposit and withdraw money, pay bills, and conduct daily business transactions using their current accounts.

4. Tax compliance: Current accounts are cru
answers: Current account offers a lot of benefits for sole proprietors. Think of it like bank account for a company. The bank provides a host of facilities for the company. A sole proprietor does not have enough value as that of a company for a bank but needs similar services. Thus Indian banks offer a toned down version of the account offered to a company. Current account offer very good overdraft ( withdrawing money even if balance is zero). This feature is very useful as  business cycles and payment schedules can be different for each supplier/customer the sole proprietor does business with. Imagine the sole proprietor account has balance of zero on day 0. customer X made payment by cheque on day 1. Cheques will get credited only on Day 3 (Assume Day 2 is a national holiday or weekend).  Sole proprietor gave a cheque to his supplier on day 0. The supplier deposited the cheque on Day 0 and the sole proprietor's bank will debit the the proprietor's account on day 1. As customer's cheque will get credited only day 3, the overdraft facility will let the proprietor borrow from the bank Interestingly, current accounts were offered long before Indian banks started  offering customized accounts to corporate customers. The payment schedule mentioned in my example is based on a clearing system > 10 years ago. Systems have become much simpler now but banks have always managed to offer something significantly extra on lines similar to my example above to proprietor over a savings bank account

Therefore, a central bank may intervene to prevent the currency from appreciating to maintain export competitiveness.
2. Inflation: Appreciation of a currency can lead to higher prices for imports, which can contribute to inflation. If a central bank aims to keep inflation low, it may intervene to prevent the currency from appreciating.

This can create economic volatility and make it difficult for the central bank to manage monetary policy. Therefore, a central bank may intervene to prevent the currency from appreciating to maintain control over capital flows.
4. Political Stability: A strong currency can make a country's imports cheaper, which can lead to higher living standards and greater purchasing power. However, this can also lead to a decrease in the domestic production of goods and services, which can have political implications. A central bank may intervene

3. Mortgage payments: As you pay off your mortgage, you increase your stake in the property and the corresponding home equity.
4. Property taxes: As property values increase, so do taxes. While this may not directly impact home equity, it can affect your property's value and appreciation.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Great, I'd be happy to help! Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all types of financial instruments, but they serve different purposes and have different characteristics. Here's a brief overview of each:

1. Convertible Debt: Convertible debt is a type of loan that can be converted into equity (i.e. stock) at a later date, typically upon an IPO (initial public offering) or other significant financing event. This feature allows investors to benefit from the potential upside of the company's growth while also receiving interest payments on their investment.
2. Convertible Notes: Convertible notes are similar to convertible debt, but they are typically shorter-term and offer lower interest payments. They are often used as an alternative to equity investment, as they provide similar upside to the company's growth while offering a more stable return on investment.
3. Bonds: Bonds are a type of debt financing in which an investor lends money to a company in exchange for regular interest payments and the return of their principal investment at maturity. Unlike convertible debt and notes, bonds do not usually have a conversion option and offer a fixed return on investment.
4. Debentures: Debentures are a type of long-term debt financing that typically does
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

answers: There are certain situations where you could legally pay yourself rent, but it'd be in the context of multiple business entities interacting, never in the context of an individual renting their own property.  Even if you could, any rent paid to yourself would count as rental income, so there'd be no benefit. Edit: I was hunting for examples where it might be acceptable, and didn't, but I found a good explanation as to why it is not acceptable from Brandon Hall on a BiggerPockets post: To get technical, you will be going up against the Economic Substance   Doctrine which states that a transaction has economic substance if:   (1) the transaction changes in a meaningful way (apart from Federal   income tax effects) the taxpayer’s economic position; and (2) the   taxpayer has a substantial purpose (apart from Federal income tax   effects) for entering into such transaction. By transferring your primary residence into a LLC, you would not be   changing your economic position. Further, you do not have a   substantial purpose for entering into such transaction other than to   simply avoid paying federal income taxes. So it might make sense if multiple people owned the LLC that owned the property you wanted to rent, and there are instances where company X owns holding company Y that owns an office building that company X rents space in. But if you're the sole player in the LLC's then it sounds like a no-go.

When a credit cardholder charges more than their available credit limit, the excess amount is called a "debit." In this situation, the credit card issuer may charge interest on the entire debit amount, even if the cardholder has already paid their minimum payment for the month.

The credit card agreement will dictate how long the interest is charged on the excess debit amount. Some credit card agreements may continue to charge interest on the entire debit amount until it is paid off, while others may only charge interest on the amount exceeding the credit limit for a certain period, such as 20-30 days.

It's important to understand that the interest charges on a debit amount can add up quickly, so it's important to make timely payments towards the entire debit amount, including the interest charges, to avoid accumulating debt and negatively impacting your credit score. If you're unable to pay off the entire debit amount, consider consolidating your debt through a balance transfer credit card or speak with a credit counselor to create a plan to manage your debt.

answers: The best answer to this is: Read the fine print on your credit card agreement. What is common, at least in the US, is that you can make any charges you want during a time window.  When the date comes around that your statement balance is calculated, you will owe interest on any amount that is showing up as outstanding in your account.  Example...  To revise the example you gave, let's say Jan 1. your account balance was $0. Jan. 3rd you went out and spent $1,000.  Your account statement will be prepared every XX days... usually 30. So if your last statement was Dec. 27th, you can expect your next statement to be prepared ~Jan.24 or Jan. 27.  To be safe, (i.e. not accrue any interest charges) you will want to make sure that your balance shows $0 when your statement is next prepared.  So back to the example you gave--if your balance showed $1,000... and you paid it off, but then charged $2,000 to it... so that there was now a new set of $2,000 charges in your account, then the bank would begin charging you interest when your next statement was prepared.  Note that there are some cards that give you a certain number of days to pay off charges before accruing interest... it just goes back to my saying "the best answer is read the fine print on your card agreement."

No, dividends are not the only thing that links stocks to corporate performance. While dividends are an important factor in determining the stock price and the overall valuation of a company, there are other key metrics that can impact the stock's performance and the company's financial health.

Some of these metrics include:

1. Earnings: A company's earnings, or profitability, is a significant factor in determining its stock price. Companies that consistently report strong earnings are likely to see their stock price rise, while those that report weak earnings may see their stock price decline.

3. Cash flow: Cash flow is another important metric that can impact a company's stock price. Companies that have strong cash flow are better positioned to invest in their business, pay dividends, and weather economic downturns.
4. Valuation multiples: The valuation multiples of a company, such as its price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio, can also impact its stock price. Companies with high valuation multiples may see their stock
answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

4. Liquidity providers: Professional liquidity providers, who help facilitate trading in the market by supplying or absorbing liquidity, may also contribute
answers: A huge amount of money in all financial markets is from institutional investors, such as mutual funds, government pension plans, sovereign wealth funds, etc.  For various reasons these funds do all of their trading at the end of the day.  They care primarily that their end-of-day balances are in line with their targets and are easy to audit and far less about "timing the market" for the best possible trades. So, if you're looking at a stock that is owned by many institutional investors -- such as a stock (like AAPL) that makes up a significant portion of an index that many funds track -- there will be a huge amount of activity at this time relative to stocks that are less popular among institutions. Even just in its introduction this paper (PDF) gives a fair overview of other reasons why there's a lot of trading at end-of-day in general. (In fact, because of all this closing activity and the reliance on end-of-day prices as signposts for financial calculations, the end-of-day has for decades been the single most fraud-ridden time of the trading day.  Electronic trading has done away with a lot of the straight-up thievery that floor traders and brokers used to get away with at the expense of the public, but it still exists.  See, for example, any explanation of the term banging the close, or the penalties against 6 banks just last month for manipulating the FX market at the close.)

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Can an ETF perform differently than its holdings?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, an ETF (Exchange-traded fund) can perform differently than its holdings. There are several reasons why this might happen:

1. Tracking error: ETFs are designed to track the performance of a particular index or asset class, but they don't always perform exactly in line with their benchmark. This is known as a tracking error, and it can be caused by a variety of factors, including trading costs, market impact, and the way the ETF's holdings are invested.
2. Manager discretion: Many ETFs are actively managed, which means the portfolio manager has some discretion to decide which securities to buy, sell, or hold. This can lead to differences between the ETF's performance and the performance of its underlying holdings, especially if the manager makes decisions that are not in line with the index or strategy.
3. Rebalancing: ETFs typically have a regular rebalancing process, which involves adjusting the portfolio's weightings to match the target benchmark. This can cause the ETF's performance to diverge from the performance of its holdings, particularly if the rebalancing occurs at times when the market is volatile.
4. Currency exposure: Some ETFs hold foreign securities, and the performance of those securities can be affected by currency fluctuations.
answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

As mhoran_psprep said, some of it goes to pay interest to the depositors; some of it goes to pay the bank's expenses like employee salaries, cost of the building, etc; and some of it goes as profit to the owners or stockholders of the bank. If you're thinking, "Wow, I'm paying back a whole lot more than I borrowed", well, yes. But remember you're borrowing that money for 20 or 30 years. The bank isn't making very much money on the loan each year that you have it -- these days something like 4 or 5% in the U.S., I don't know what the going rates are in other countries.

Gilts are eligible securities on which interest can be paid. The interest rate paid by the government on Gilts is called the gilt yield. It is set at the auction when the gilt is issued, based on the demand for that particular gilt. The gilt yield is influenced by various factors, such as inflation, economic growth, and interest rate expectations. Repayments:
Gilts are typically issued for a period of 10, 20, or 30 years, with a fixed interest rate. At the end of the term, the investor receives the principal amount back, along with any accrued interest. The repayment of the principal is called maturity. The repayment amount is not affected by inflation, as the interest rate is fixed.

answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

For tax purposes, the IRS considers gifts "counted" when they are made and recorded in the calendar year in which they were given. This means that gifts given in one tax year will be eligible for tax deductions in that year, while gifts given in the following year will be eligible for deductions in the following tax year.

The IRS defines a tax year as the 12 months ending on December 31st of each calendar year. For example, the 2022 tax year will run from January 1, 2022, to December 31, 2022, and gifts made during this time will be eligible for tax deductions in the 2022 tax year. Similarly, gifts made on December 31, 2022, will be eligible for tax deductions in the 2023 tax year.

It's important to keep accurate records of all gifts given, including the date of the gift, the amount given, and the name and address of the recipient. Receipts or other documentation of the gifts should be kept with other tax-related documents, such as your tax return and supporting schedules.

The ask price is the price at which a security can be bought or sold on the market. The bid price, on the other hand, is the price at which a market participant is willing to sell a security. The spread between the two prices represents the profit margin of the market maker or dealer.

By purchasing a security at a price lower than the ask price or between the bid and ask prices, you can potentially buy it at a discount. There are several benefits to using a bid or bidding strategy:

1. Potential savings: By purchasing a security at a lower price, you can save money compared to buying it at the ask price.

answers: This sometimes happens to me. It depends on how liquid the option is. Normally what I see happening is that the order book mutates itself around my order. answers: The price of the last trade... Is the price of the last trade. It indicates what one particular buyer and seller agreed upon. There is absolutely no requirement that one of them didn't offer too much or demand too little, so this is nearly meaningless as an indication of what anyone else will be willing to offer or demand. Or you tell the broker what the limits are that you consider acceptable, trading these risks off against each other. In contrast, bad debt, also known as unproductive debt, refers to debt that is incurred for consumptive purchases that do not generate any long-term value, such as credit card debt or personal loans.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, the wash sale rules are different for stocks, ETFs, and mutual funds. The wash sale rule is a tax provision that aims to prevent investors from claiming a loss on the sale of an investment without actually realizing the loss. The rule states that if an investor sells a security at a loss and purchases a “substantially identical” security within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss may be disallowed for tax purposes.

For stocks, the wash sale rule is applied based on the specific stock that was sold. If an investor sells a stock at a loss and buys “substantially identical” stock within 30 days, the loss may be disallowed. The term “substantially identical” means that the new stock must be identical to the one sold, including its underlying rights, options, and other characteristics.

For ETFs and mutual funds, the wash sale rule is applied differently. Instead of focusing on the specific security, the rule looks at the underlying securities. If an investor sells an ETF or mutual fund at a loss and purchases a substantially identical ETF or mutual fund within 30 days, the loss may be disallowed. The term “substantially identical” here refers to the underlying holdings of the ETF or mutual
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing. Both are important financial metrics used in real estate valuation and analysis, but they measure different aspects of a property's financial performance.

Capitalization rate, also known as the cap rate, is the rate of return on investment based on the property's net operating income (NOI) and purchase price. It is calculated by dividing the NOI by the property's purchase price, expressed as a percentage. For example, if a property generates $100,000 in NOI and cost $1 million to purchase, the capitalization rate would be 10% ($100,000 / $1 million). Capitalization rate is used to estimate the potential return on investment for a real estate investor.

Net profit margin, on the other hand, is a measure of a property's profitability, expressed as a percentage of the property's total revenue. It represents the amount of each dollar of revenue that goes towards covering operating costs and generating profits. For example, if a property generates $100,000 in revenue and $50,000 in operating costs, the net profit margin would be 50% ($50,000 / $100,000). Net profit margin is used to evaluate the financial performance of a property
answers: Both of these terms do refer to your profit; they're just different ways of evaluating it. First, your definition of capitalization rate is flipped.  As explained here, it should be: On the other hand, as explained here: So cap rate is like a reverse unit cost approach to comparing two investments.  If house A costs $1M and you'll make $50K (profit) from it yearly, and house B costs $1.33M and you'll make $65K (profit) from it yearly, then you can compute cap rates to see that A is a more efficient investment from the point of view of income vs. amount-of-money-you-have-stuck-in-this-investment-and-unavailable-for-use-elsewhere. Profit margin, on the other hand, cares more about your ongoing expenses than about your total investment.  If it costs less to maintain property B than it does to maintain property A, then you could have something like: So B is a more efficient investment from the point of view of the fraction of your revenue you actually get to keep each year. Certainly you could think of the property's value as an opportunity cost and factor that into the net profit margin equation to get a more robust estimate of exactly how efficient your investment is.  You can keep piling more factors into the equation until you've accounted for every possible facet of your investment.  This is what accountants and economists spend their days doing. :-)

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
One "lot" of EUR/USD refers to a standard unit of trade in the foreign exchange market, which is typically equivalent to 100,000 units of the base currency (in this case, Euros) traded against the quote currency (US Dollars). This means that if you are trading EUR/USD, one lot is equal to 100,000 Euros worth of US Dollars.

The term "lot" was established by the interbank market to simplify transactions and make them more manageable for traders. By using standardized lots, banks can easily quote prices, calculate profits and losses, and manage risk.

However, it's important to note that traders can trade fractions of a lot, known as "fractional lots." For example, if you want to trade 50,000 Euros worth of US Dollars, you could do so by buying or selling 0.5 lots of EUR/USD.

It's also worth noting that some brokers may have their own definition of a lot, depending on their margin requirements and other factors. Be sure to check with your broker to understand their specific lot size and any associated requirements.

In summary, one lot of EUR/USD is equal to 100,000 Euros worth
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) can be taxed as long-term capital gains depending on the holding period and the individual's tax situation.

In general, RSUs are considered to be taxable as ordinary income when they are vest and settled. The employee must include in their income the fair market value of the shares received as RSUs at the time of vesting, which is typically the grant date or the vesting date. However, if the RSUs are held for more than one year (i.e., they are a long-term capital asset), the gain on their sale would be eligible for the lower long-term capital gains tax rate, rather than the higher ordinary income tax rate.

To qualify for the long-term capital gains treatment, the RSUs must be held for at least one year after they are vest and settled. If the holding period is less than one year, the gain on the sale of the RSUs would be considered ordinary income, subject to the higher tax rate. For example, suppose you received an RSU grant in 2022 and it vested and settled in 2023. If you sell the shares in 2024, the gain would be eligible for the long-term capital gains treatment if you held the shares for at least 12 months following the vesting and settlement date

Further, the company would withhold 25% of the VEST for federal taxes and 10% for state taxes, if I lived in a state with income tax. The withholding rate was flat, regardless of what my actual tax rate was. Capital gains on the change from the market value on the VEST date was calculated as short-term or long-term based on the time since the VEST date. So if my 100 shares went up to $120, I would pay the $20 difference as short term or long term based on how long I had owned them since the VEST. That said, I don't know if this is universal. As a helpful assistant, I can tell you that the ability of a check to be honored depends on several factors, including the age of the check, the financial status of the issuer, and the availability of funds in the issuer's account.

If the check is more than 6 months old, it may be considered stale-dated and may no longer be valid. Banks have the discretion to honor or decline a stale-dated check, and it's not guaranteed that it will be honored.

If the issuer's account has insufficient funds to cover the check, it will likely be returned to the payee for lack of funds. This can happen even if the check is less than 6 months old.

In some cases, the issuer may have closed their account or have had their account restricted, in which case the check may not be honored.

It's important to verify with the bank that the check can still be honored before attempting to cash it. You can contact the issuer's bank to confirm their current account status or use a check verification service to determine if the check is valid and whether there are any issues with the account.

In summary, the ability of a check to be honored depends on various factors, and it's important to verify its validity before attempting to cash it.

prompt:

What is a subsidy?[/INST]
pred:
A subsidy is a form of financial assistance provided by a government or other organization to support a particular activity or industry. Subsidies are typically used to reduce the cost of a product or service, make it more affordable for consumers, or to promote economic growth and development in a particular sector.

There are several types of subsidies, including:

1. Direct subsidies: These are subsidies that are directly provided to an individual, business, or organization. Examples include grants, loans, and tax credits.
2. Indirect subsidies: These are subsidies that are not directly provided to an individual or business, but rather are built into the prices of goods or services. For example, a government may provide funding for a public transportation system, which in turn reduces the cost of transportation for consumers.
3. Trade subsidies: These are subsidies that are provided to businesses or industries to promote exports or to help them compete with businesses in other countries.
4. Production subsidies: These are subsidies that are provided to farmers or other producers to help them produce goods at a lower cost or to promote the production of specific crops or products.

Subsidies can have both positive and negative impacts on the economy. On the one hand, subsidies can promote economic growth and development by providing
answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. For example, if there are different quality kinds of crops that can be planted, for example a GM maize that brings in high yields but can only be processed to High Fructose Corn Syrup or a naturally bred corn that brings lower yields but tastes well enough for direct consumption, then if demand for both exceeds supply, the economic choice for the individual farmer is to plant the former. If the claims that HFCS contribute to obesity are founded, then it is in the public interest to produce less of it, and more alternative foods. Given that a market rather than a planned economy is desired, this cannot be achieved by decree, but rather money is used as an incentive. In the long term, this investment may very well pay off through reduced health care costs, so it is a rational economic decision from the state's point of view. In a world where all actors make decisions that are fully in their self interest, in principle subsidies would not be needed as consumers would demand healthy rather than cheap foods, and market mechanisms would provide these.

Is it a bet on price fluctuations and against the house?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, sports betting is generally considered a bet on price fluctuations, rather than a direct bet against the house. When you place a bet on a sporting event, you are predicting the outcome of the game or event, and the odds provided by the bookmaker reflect the probability of that outcome occurring.

In sports betting, the bookmaker acts as a middleman, taking bets from both sides of a given event. The bookmaker sets the odds for each possible outcome, and bettors can choose to bet on the outcome they think is most likely to occur. The bookmaker makes a profit by charging a commission, called the "vig" or "juice," on every bet placed.

The key to success in sports betting is understanding the odds and the probability of different outcomes occurring. By doing so, you can make informed betting decisions and increase your chances of winning. This requires a combination of knowledge about the teams, players, and other factors that can influence the outcome of a game, as well as an understanding of the odds and how they are calculated.

It's important to note that sports betting is not a guaranteed way to make money, and there are no shortcuts or "systems" that can guarantee success. It's a form of gambling, and like any other form of gambling, there is always an element
answers: The answer depends on the specific instrument to which you are referring. It is possible to make straight bets that are cash-settled and in which the underlying commodity or instrument will never be bought or sold.  It is also possible to have such a contract be settled in the underlying (if the cash value is appropriate, then the cash settlement can be used to purchase the underlying directly, if necessary).  Physical delivery was predominant until the last few decades.  Most traders, as opposed to hedgers or strategics, are going to prefer cash-settled contracts as opposed to physical delivery. It is possible to make trades with a brokerage firm such that the firm pays if the trader wins the bet.  The firm will typically find parties on the other side to even out this bet and leave itself neutral as to the outcome (plus a small premium it charges each side for the cost of making the market).  The cost charged to one contracting party should be set by the dealer in relation to prices being charged to parties making the opposite, matching bet (in this way, brokers are following market price, while traders are setting it). Financially, options and contracts can be settled for cash or for the underlying, and they can be made directly with the opposite bettor or with a neutral dealer.

answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as going short, is a financial investment strategy that involves selling securities that the investor does not own with the expectation of repurchasing them at a lower price to realize a profit. In other words, an investor borrows shares of a stock from a broker and sells them at the current market price, with the intention of buying back the same shares at a lower price later to return to the lender.

The basic idea behind short selling is that the price of a stock can decrease, and the investor can buy back the shares at the lower price to make a profit. This strategy is considered a hedge against potential market losses, as the investor can limit their losses by buying back the shares at a lower price if the market turns against them.

Short selling can be used to profit from a decline in the price of a stock, but it also carries significant risks. If the price of the stock rises instead of falls, the investor will be required to buy back the shares at a higher price, resulting in a loss. Short sellers are often subject to additional risks, such as margin calls and the potential for unlimited losses, as the broker can demand immediate payment of any losses if the price of the stock rises significantly.

Short selling is commonly used by professional investors, such as hedge funds, as well as
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

A tender offer is a financial transaction where a company or individual offers to purchase shares of their own stock from existing shareholders at a specified price. However, it is possible for a tender offer to be less than the market price for several reasons:

2. Shareholder sentiment: If investors are bearish on the company's prospects or have concerns about its valuation, they may be more likely to sell their shares at a discounted price. In such cases, the tender offer price may be lower than the market price to reflect investor sentiment.

answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. For instance, a large public company that contracts with a smaller supplier or service company, also public, might make a tender offer below market price. The market will look at this price and the business relationship, and wonder what the larger company knows about the smaller one that they don't. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The company making the tender offer can then get its shares either way; directly via the offer, or on the open market. Here are some factors to consider when determining whether something is a gift or a payment for service:

3. Quantity and Value: If the service or good being provided has a low value or quantity, it may be considered a gift. As the value or quantity of the service or good increases, it becomes more likely to be viewed as a payment.

answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. This number is adjusted annually for inflation. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. In Minnesota, it starts at 1 million.  The federal tax is paid for by the person making the gift, unless other arrangements are made. There is an annual exclusion amount of approximately $14,000. You can give up to this amount to any number of recipients and it is not considered taxable. Therefore, when you give $100 to someone, it is not a taxable event.  If you do make a gift to an individual in excess of 14k, you'll need to file a gift tax return (IRS Form 709). When you file form 709, you won't need to pay taxes until the 5.34 million is exceeded. Instead, you can claim an exemption. Since most people don't exceed that amount, its rare to ever pay taxes even when exceeding the annual exclusion amount. The annual exclusion amount is adjusted each year for inflation.

The U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year. Under the U.S. tax code, Section 114 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC), gains realised in a tax year are taxed in that year. This means that any gains made in a prior fiscal year cannot be taxed again in a subsequent fiscal year.

For example, if a taxpayer realises gains in January of the 2022 fiscal year, those gains would be taxed in the 2022 tax year, and would not be subject to taxation in a future fiscal year. Similarly, if a taxpayer realises losses in February of the 2022 fiscal year, those losses would not be eligible for a refund in a subsequent fiscal year.

There are, however, some limited exceptions to this rule. For instance, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) included a provision that allows taxpayers to "push" certain unrealised capital gains to the tax year in which they are realised, if the gains are attributable to the sale of a business or the sale of certain types of investments (such as partnership interests or S corporation stock). However, these exceptions are limited and do not generally apply to gains realised outside
answers: You're certainly referring to "Ex Post Facto" laws, and while the US is constitutionally prohibited from passing criminal laws that are retroactive, the US Supreme Court has upheld many tax laws that apply tax code changes retroactively. You might ask a similar question on Law.SE for a more thorough treatment of the legalities of congress passing those laws, but I will stick to the personal finance portion of the question. What this means is that you can't expect that the current tax laws will be in force in the future, and your investment/retirement plans should be as flexible as possible. You may wish to have some money in both Roth and traditional 401(k) accounts. You might not want to have millions of dollars in Roth accounts, because if congress does act to limit the tax benefits of those accounts, it will probably be targeting the larger balances. If you are valuing tax deductions, you should put slightly more weight on deductions that you can take today than deductions that would apply in the future. If you do find yourself in trouble because of a retroactive change, be sure to consult a tax lawyer that specializes in dealing with the IRS to possibly negotiate a settlement for a lower amount than the full tax bill that results from the changes.

What is the opposite of Economic Bubble? [/INST]
pred:
The opposite of an economic bubble is a sustainable economy, characterized by stable and fundamentally sound financial market conditions. A sustainable economy is one where economic growth is driven by fundamental factors such as productivity gains, innovation, and solid fundamentals, rather than by speculative or artificially inflated market conditions.

In a sustainable economy, asset prices are driven by underlying value and are not influenced by excessive speculation or misallocated capital. As a result, the economy is less susceptible to sudden and drastic changes, and is better equipped to absorb shocks and adjust to changing economic conditions.

Some key features of a sustainable economy include:

1. Stable and low inflation: Prices are stable and low, with minimal fluctuations in the overall level of prices.
2. Sustainable growth: Economic growth is sustained and fundamentally driven by underlying factors such as productivity and innovation, rather than by speculative or artificially inflated market conditions.
3. Strong fundamentals: The economy is characterized by strong and stable financial fundamentals, including a solid balance sheet, low debt levels, and a stable financial system.
4. Resilience: The economy is better able to withstand shocks and surprises, and is more resilient to economic downturns and
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

6. Signature: The payor must sign the check to validate the payment.
7. Magnetic Ink Character Recognition (MICR) Number: Most checks also include a MICR number, which is a machine-readable code that contains the account number and other information.

What does a Dividend “will not be quoted ex” mean?[/INST]
pred:
A dividend "will not be quoted ex" refers to a situation where a company decides not to provide an ex-dividend date for its shares. In other words, the company will not distribute the dividend to its shareholders who buy or sell the stock at any point before the record date for the dividend.

Ex-dividend (or "ex-div") is a term used in the stock market to indicate that a company has declared a dividend and will distribute it to its shareholders on a specific date. When a company declares a dividend, it sets a record date to determine who is entitled to receive the dividend. Shareholders must buy or sell their stock before the record date to receive the dividend.

In the case of a dividend "will not be quoted ex," the company is informing investors that it will not set an ex-dividend date for the upcoming dividend. This means that investors who buy or sell shares of the company's stock after the record date will still receive the dividend, even if they purchase or sell on a date later than the record date.

This type of announcement is typically made by companies that do not want to distribute a dividend for a particular quarter or year, or that do not want to disclose their dividend payment date. It is important for investors to be aware of this information
answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off.  In such a case, the rights to, and the spin-off itself may be quoted separately on the home country exchange.  However, if the company is based abroad, it may not be worth the expense for them to have an additional securities listing on the local (US) exchange. For example:  In November 2016, Yamana Gold (TSX: YRI, NYSE: AUY) announced it will have an initial public offering of a spin-off (Brio Gold, to be listed on TSX as BRIO). These rights were separately traded in advance of the IPO of the spin-off on TSX under "YRI.RT", but the prospectus they stated that the rights "will not be quoted ex" on NYSE, i.e. there was no separate listing on NYSE for these rights. The wording seems counter-intuitive, but I suspect that is the attorneys who were preparing the prospectus used those specific words as they may have a very specific meaning (e.g. from a statute or previous case).
